To write a Pig Latin transformer in Julia that operates on a vector of strings and runs each iteration on a separate thread, you can use the `Threads` module to parallelize the processing. Below is an example implementation of such a function:

```julia
using Threads

function pig_latinify(input_strings::Vector{String})
    output_strings = Vector{String}(undef, length(input_strings))
    Threads.@threads for (i, input_string) in enumerate(input_strings)
        output_strings[i] = pig_latin(input_string)
    end
    return output_strings
end
```

The `pig_latinify` function uses the `Threads.@threads` macro to parallelize the loop over each string in the vector. This will create a separate thread for each iteration of the loop. The `pig_latin` function should be implemented to convert a single string into its Pig Latin equivalent.

Please note that the `Threads.@threads` macro is a high-level parallelization tool and may not always result in performance gains due to thread creation overhead, especially if the work per thread is very small. In such cases, it might be more efficient to use other parallelization techniques or process larger chunks of data at once.
